body:
Benjamin, I think actually that the best way forward is simply for you to maintain this gem on the side. It doesn't matter that it's duplicated in Rails. Your gem is there for anyone who wants to use this outside of Rails. Then we don't have to bother with integration or deprecation or another dependency.

On Sep 10, 2013, at 2:32 PM, Benjamin Fleischer <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> The touch points of the gem within Rails are minimal.
> 
> 	• rake lines and tools/profiler were dev tasks, not surfaced in a release
> 	• rake stats is now configured much more easily. The only part of it that would really need to be synced with Rails would be 1) the default directories and 2) the Railtie.
> Note: The code that determines which directories to run on, what to name the stats, and if they are tests is much more flexible now. It does include the Rails defaults, but otherwise is independent of Rails and has a backwards compatible API.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
>
